message_1: A manufacturing company produces light bulbs with a mean life of 1000 hours and a standard deviation of 50 hours. Find the probability that a randomly selected light bulb will last more than 1100 hours.
message_2:
To find the probability that a randomly selected light bulb will last more than 1100 hours, we can use the z-score formula and the standard normal distribution table.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we want to find the probability for (1100 hours), μ is the mean (1000 hours), and σ is the standard deviation (50 hours).

First, let's find the z-score:

z = (1100 - 1000) / 50
z = 100 / 50
z = 2

Now, we can use the standard normal distribution table to find the probability that a randomly selected light bulb will have a z-score greater than 2. The table gives us the probability that a value is less than a given z-score, so we need to find the complement of the probability.

P(Z > 2) = 1 - P(Z < 2)

Looking up the z-score of 2 in the standard normal distribution table, we find that P(Z < 2) ≈ 0.9772.

Therefore, the probability that a randomly selected light bulb will last more than 1100 hours is:

P(Z > 2) = 1 - 0.9772
P(Z > 2) ≈ 0.0228

So, there is approximately a 2.28% chance that a randomly selected light bulb will last more than 1100 hours.
